title: 114_s278
content: The "Citizen Empowerment Act" may be cited as the official title. Part III of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding a new chapter 79A for services to members of the public. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" establishes procedures for in-person and telephonic interactions by executive branch employees regarding possible violations of federal statutes or regulations. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" defines terms such as violation, State, and telephonic. It also requires employees to allow individuals to make audio recordings of covered interactions. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" allows individuals to make audio recordings of covered interactions with Executive agency employees at their own expense and with their own equipment. Employees conducting interactions can also record them, but must inform the individual and provide a transcript or copy upon request with reimbursement. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" requires Executive agency employees to inform individuals of recording before interactions and provide transcripts upon request with reimbursement. Employees must also explain individuals' rights before or at the initial interaction. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" mandates that Executive agency employees must notify individuals of their recording rights before any interaction. Separate notifications are required for different violations. Additionally, individuals represented by an official representative or power of attorney are allowed to make audio recordings of covered interactions with agency employees. Official representatives or those with power of attorney can make audio recordings of covered interactions with Executive agency employees. They are allowed to receive transcripts or copies of the recordings and must be given the same notice as the individual involved. Official representatives or those with power of attorney can make audio recordings of covered interactions with Executive agency employees. They are allowed to receive transcripts or copies of the recordings and must be given the same notice as the individual involved. The audio recordings and transcripts made by an individual or provided to them shall be the individual's property, and there is no private right of action created by this section. Exceptions include classified information, public safety, and criminal matters. The transcript of an audio recording made by an individual or provided to them is the individual's property. This section does not create a private right of action. Exceptions include classified information, public safety, and criminal investigations. Exceptions to the rule that allows individuals to make audio recordings include classified information, public safety concerns, and ongoing criminal investigations conducted by federal law enforcement officers. Employees must notify individuals if an exception applies to their recording. The section requires written notification to individuals who are not allowed to make audio recordings of covered interactions. It supersedes previous laws related to recording interactions and mandates disciplinary action for violating employees. The section mandates disciplinary action for employees of Executive agencies who violate the prohibition on making audio recordings of covered interactions. Services to members of the public are regulated under section 7921.
